oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lynchburg Historic District: Bean-West House side view
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: West, Carroll Van
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Bounded by majors, Main, Elm, and Wall Streets, Lynchburg, Moore County, TN

Color photograph of a 1876 two story Carpenter Gothic triple gable house has two street side facades, each with triple cross gables within a side gabled roof, stone foundation with poured concrete porch section on the Majors street facade, vinyl siding and pressed metal shingle roof; the 3/4 porch facing Majors has a shed roof with asphalt shingles, spindlework railing, and scroll sawn porch supports; front entry faceade, facing Main street, has a side gabled roof with triple gable wall dormers, two of which contain six over six double hung sash windows within pointed, Gothic style recesses with wood bracing; center gable dormer has gingerbread details in a series of three progressively smaller triangles; two brick interior chimneys flank center dormer; full porch sith spindlework railing and frieze has plain wooden posts and contains a center multi-paned door with single pane sidelights and wood pilasters, flanked by single six over six double hung sash windows with wood shutters.

The Lynchburg Historic District is comprised of eighty-two properties which make up the central part of the community, located in Moore County, TN. Lynchburg was designated as the county seat of the newly established Moore County in 1871. It is also the commercial and industrial center for the county. The area contains buildings that represent the development of Lynchburg from a crossroads community into the political and commercial center of Moore County. The integrity of the district is evident not only in the historic buildings, but in the layout of the town, which reflects the impact of the county seat designation. The focus of the historic district is a downtown core which surrounds the courthouse block and is known as the Public Square.
